fields.description:
Kicking off many sqoop processes in different threads results in:

{code}

If two are kicked off in the same second. The issue is the following lines of code in the org.apache.hadoop.mapred.LocalDistributedCacheManager class: 

{code}
    // Generating unique numbers for FSDownload.
    AtomicLong uniqueNumberGenerator =
       new AtomicLong(System.currentTimeMillis());
{code}

and 

{code}
Long.toString(uniqueNumberGenerator.incrementAndGet())),
{code}

Thanks to report this issue.
I looked at the patch, How about to use JobID_timestamp as the unique directory name?
Use random number, we loose timestamp information which may be useful for debug purpose.
add JobID, we will have more information to help debug.
LocalDistributedCacheManager doesn't have jobID information, but we can pass the JobID information to LocalDistributedCacheManager from LocalJobRunner.

[~wattsinabox] [~zxu] Thank you for taking this JIRA. I think JobID + timestamp can conflict and don't resolve the problem. It makes sense to use randomUUID here. If we need more readability, JobID + randomUUID is better. Does this make sense?
BTW, It's better to add a test to access the directories from multiple threads(e.g. thousands threads).

Should be fine. The purpose was to guarantee different job directories and that's what the comment says.

I'll try these suggested changes and check the tests.

[~zxu] I tried your suggestion; however TestMRWithDistributedCache does not pass with JobId on its own. Trying [~ozawa]'s suggestion worked and improved the readability. So I'm submitting a new patch with the UUID and the jobID together. 

However, this involved changing the setup method signature so we could pass in the job ID. Please let me know if I should've done this another way, but I didn't see the Job ID in the configuration.

Submitting the patch in a few minutes.

Also, I wanted to ask how I could do your test suggestion, [~ozawa]. I'm not super familiar with this code base, but I would be happy to attempt such a test, if its needed. The aforementioned TestMRWithDistributedCache seems to catch any problems with the directory name, just FYI.

FYI, I just filed and closed MAPREDUCE-6685 today as a duplicate.  Some comments from my experiments on that JIRA:

- JobID or process ID were the only unique things I could think of on separate processes.

- The only downside I saw to using UUID#randomUUID() was that it was still based on timestamp (granted, with 100ns resolution).  I'm guessing that it might be more CPU intensive than Random#nextLong(), assuming the difference comes from System#currentTimeMillis() vs System#nanoTime().

- The solution in MAPREDUCE-6685 did seeding Random with process ID as the RNG instead and skipping modifying the method signature (either is fine as far as I can tell).

That being said, this solution looks fine to me.

Minor nitpick: Please do "git add" and verify with "git status" before generating the patch (either that or clobber the patch file and don't append).  The resulting file is much easier to read.

Changed to Executor model for unit test.  This is my third attempt at a unit test, but I haven't managed to get it to fail with the old code.

bq. but I haven't managed to get it to fail with the old code
My understanding is that the new test is supposed to fail with the old code and the new change is supposed to fix the test failure. Otherwise, the new test is not testing any new behavior, right?

Yeah, but this method has an issue with Pig/Sqoop which actually launches separate MR processes locally that causes this collision.  I haven't figured out a good way to duplicate simultaneous directory creation (even multithreaded) reliably, but I'm open to suggestions.

I see. Talking with Daniel, there is really no good way to do this. Can we then add a javadoc to this new method to explain the issue with the test?
As suggested by Daniel, we should probably use Barrier (All threads wait on the barrier and get notified at the same time) which will give us better chance to reproduce this.

So, I tried a couple of ways using Barrier, but it didn't seem to make a difference.

* Added documentation about test caveats
* Add usage of Barrier for coordinating launching
